title: Darwins Medicine: Evolutionary psychology and its applications
abstractText:
This grant was a contribution to the 2009 Darwin Bicentennial celebrations.

The main aim of this seminar series was to integrate current research in evolutionary psychology with key areas of application and social policy and to provide a link between academic researchers and those involved in making and implementing policy in both private and public sectors.

We ran six one-day workshop seminars, each with 4-6 speakers, at University of Oxford, University of Edinburgh, University of Kent, London Business School, Brunel University and University College London.

A total of 37 speakers contributed to the seminars on six broad topics (social networks, security and terrorism, charity-giving and philanthropy, leadership and management, disease and health, and inequality and the dysfunctional society.

In all, 374 delegates attended the seminars, representing 12 disciplines within the sciences, social sciences and medicine from 39 UK universities, as well as several European ones. Approximately 20 per cent of delegates were from outside academia, representing the armed forces, central and local government, the NHS, the print media, several public policy think-tanks and many commercial businesses.
